awd_abstract_narration: Our ability to understand and effectively use parallel computers           lags far behind our ability to build them.  The inherent complexity of          parallelism causes some of the difficulty.  However, programming                languages must also take some blame since they have not provided                adequate support for understanding, expressing, or managing                     parallelism.                                                                    This research addresses the problem of expressing, programming, and             debugging complex, symbolic applications on parallel computers.  Based          on past experience with compiling Lisp programs for parallel computers          and recent simulations of C programs, this research attempts to                 establish that existing languages are inappropriate for parallel                symbolic computation.  It pursues two new approaches to language                design--large- grain data parallelism and parallel abstract data                types--that will produce languages better suited to expressing and              compiling parallel programs.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations
